Award.AwardTitle: Sustained measurements of Southern Ocean air-sea coupling from a mobile autonomous platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
The coupled air-sea dynamics of the Southern Ocean play a critical role in the ocean?s transport and storage of heat and carbon dioxide and the response of these processes to climate change. This project advances our capability to observe air-sea dynamics under winds through a 6-month deployment of a wave glider. The wave glider has been adequately demonstrated as a robust high-endurance platform for open-ocean work and has begun to demonstrate its capability for research-quality measurements. This project will advance that capability by increasing our understanding of vehicle and sensor performance and suitability for measuring air?sea fluxes of momentum, moisture, and heat. Simultaneously, the vehicle will be used to study critical scientific questions on air-sea interactions. The project will include graduate and undergraduate student training and outreach activities through local schools, the Seattle Aquarium, and the Pacific Science Center.

The main research topics addressed in this project are the spatial structure of winds and surface properties in the Southern Ocean, the influence of surface wave Stokes drift on Ekman transport in the upper ocean, wave modulation of wind stress, near-inertial wind energy input into the ocean, and the coupling between winds and sea surface temperature. The observations will be taken by a Liquid Robotics Wave Glider SV3 autonomous surface vehicle instrumented for measurements of surface waves, temperature and salinity, upper-ocean currents, barometric pressure, and winds. Deployment and recovery will exploit planned cruises maintaining the Ocean Observatories Initiative Southern Ocean array and re-supplying the US Antarctic Program's Palmer Station. The sampling plan consists of (1) three months near the Ocean Observatories Initiative air-sea interactions buoy to study spatial structure and allow cross-calibration of the various sensors and their responses to vehicle heading and wind and wave conditions; (2) two months conducting a downstream grid survey across the Antarctic Circumpolar Current towards Drake Passage; and (3) a month-long timeseries in southern Drake Passage in the weak-current region between the Polar Front and the Southern ACC Front before recovery from the R/V Laurence M. Gould.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

Air-sea interaction in the Southern Ocean connects the "conveyor belt" overturning circulations in each the major oceans of the world (Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian), providing the long-term memory of the climate system by determining the rates of oceanic heat and carbon storage over tens to hundreds of years as well as the supply of heat to melt Antarctic ice shelves. With the goal of enhancing our ability to study these air-sea interaction processes through sustained autonomous presence in remote locations, our project deployed a wave-propelled robotic surface vehicle (Wave Glider) near Palmer Station, Antarctic Peninsula, for an extended mission in Drake Passage. Over a 3 month period, the Wave Glider conducted time series stations and surveys of the Polar Front (one of the intense jets of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current). The vehicle also collected multiple instances of calibration data by positioning itself near the tracks of passing Antarctic research vessels.

Although this first extended deployment revealed some important limitations in the Wave Glider's durability and it's ability to maintain solar battery charging in the high-latitude Antarctic, the results were encouraging enough that new Wave Glider missions are continuing. A second field season was undertaken in 2019 under a new (ongoing) grant, and a new profiling winch system for subsurface temperature and salinity sampling shows great promise.

 

Intellectual Merit

The scientific goals of the Southern Ocean Wave Glider mission included the measurement of rapid wind variations (both the hourly changes of fast-moving storms and the second-to-second fluctuations of boundary layer turbulence) and small-scale horizontal structure in the ocean's near-surface currents, temperature, and salinity. These, along with the surface wave field, have important impacts on the rates of air-sea transfer of momentum and heat (which, in turn, drives the ocean circulation). Through the measurements collected, we have been able to demonstrate that a Wave Glider is able to collect reliable measurements of surface conditions (including turbulence) and will be a valuable tool for improving momentum and heat transfer estimates.

Over the course of its mission, the Wave Glider's multiple crossings of the Polar Front illustrated the response of both air temperature and winds to ocean surface temperature, as well as the impact that surface currents have on the surface wave field.

Preliminary findings from comparing wind, wave, and turbulence measurements indicate that a new wave-based theory provides improved measurements of wind forcing in most cases, while an older simpler theory continues to work better in others. The reasons for these different situations are still being investigated, but they are at least partially related to the fact that waves in the Southern Ocean are not purely driven by the local winds but can travel long distances over many days and also undergo modification by the strong currents along the way.


Broader Impacts

The work done in this project has advanced our capability for Southern Ocean science and clarified the advantages and disadvantages of using autonomous surface vehicles to make extended observations. Even in the strong Antarctic Circumpolar Current, the Wave Glider is able to conduct surveys and hold station, provided that satellite maps of the currents are used to guide the vehicle piloting. Future missions of 4-6 months duration in the Southern Hemisphere summer are entirely viable and will continue to conduct scientific studies that cannot be accomodated by the overtaxed Antarctic research vessel fleet.

The emerging relationship between surface currents and the wave field points to ways that coupled climate forecasts can be improved by taking these impacts on the drag law into account. Wind drag on the ocean determines how a strengthening of Southern Ocean winds due to increased greenhouse gases will translate into a response in the Circumpolar Current, with cascading consequences for the oceanic overturning circulation and Antarctic ecosystems.

Finally, the novel concept of the robotic Wave Glider and its role in Antarctic research has immense capacity to inspire and serve as a venue for public-facing outreach and education. All members of the research team continue to give general audience presentations, both locally (through science centers in Seattle) and nationally (through blogs, press releases, and live broadcasts from sea).
